title: Great App - Just wish it opened faster
text:
I’ve given this a strong 4/5 because I used this app all day long as a move between meetings. I most use the calendar function to check where I’m headed to next, with a close second being email reading and finally composing emails. 

There is some small functionality I wish it had from the desktop version (like a team members availability when booking a meeting) but the main drawback is the app open time from having a locked phone. This is an on-the-go app and having to wait 10 seconds with a white screen while the app loads just isn’t good enough. Note this is on iPhone 6 with 10GB remaining memory running iOS11.

title: iOS 11 support, tasks, and search
text: Please add drag and drop for iPad. Also, as I’ve stated before- if you could incorporate task management into this app the way you have incorporated calendar and attachments, it would be so much more useful — like the desktop app. Alternate request: ability to link to other apps, especially in the absence of a built-in task manager. I should be able to easily send an email or attachment to another app like OmniFocus or Fantastical to create a task or follow-up reminder. What good is a flagged email if you can’t also set a reminder for it? I’d also like to see the email Filter have more options like date received/sent, VIP contacts, etc. Lastly, it seems like the search algorithm is so much more advanced on desktop. What’s the limitation?

title: No longer opens email links in browser
text:
After the latest update, Outlook forces users to open email links in Outlook’s internal browser (much like instagram when you click profile links). This allows Microsoft to track your activity, and also results in a worse user experience, because the in-outlook browser obviously doesn’t have any of your cookies or saved passwords, nor does it render pages properly, so inevitably you have to click through a menu tree to open the link in an actual browser.

The worst part is that even if you drill down into Outlook’s settings and specifically check “open links in Safari”, Outlook still won’t do it! The app is essentially broken at this point. Whoever made the decision to do this should be fired, it’s a true strategy failure. What a waste of a good app.

title: Main issue with the Outlook app
text: It is entirely reliant on an internet connection. If you’re traveling with your cell and go through areas of poor connectivity, the app just freezes as it’s trying to communicate with the cloud. I’m actually surprised the developer didn’t predict this issue and make the app function offline and queue messages up for sending once good communication is established. ie. when you press the PLUS button to begin a new email, if you have poor internet signal, the new message pop up window won’t even open. It makes you feel like the app is frozen or that you didn’t press the button. Very annoying when you’re in a hurry to write an email. It forces you to wait until the connection is established.

title: Lackluster Contacts Functionality
text: The functionality of the Outlook contacts is absolutely horrible. My organization protects the data within Outlook, which is to be expected, however, the functionality to view and edit contact information in the native contacts app and within Outlook is incredibly limited. I suggest making any contact updates in the desktop or web version until this is resolved. The interface, ability to edit, and categorization of a Office vs. Mobile vs Main line is absolutely horrible. Upgrading the functionality and UI needs to be a priority in the next update. Nevertheless, I’m using this app is because it’s a company requirement, I would choose another application if I could, but if I’m stuck with this, I want it to work! Like many business users, it’s a captive market, forced to use an app with limited/poor functionality, especially in a core function of the app.

title: Who was the original sender
text:
I have only one issue with emails. When I receive an email that is also addressed to multiple people and one of the other recipients responds to the email,  I can no longer see the original email in my inbox as it appeared from the sender, it shows in my inbox as being from the last person to respond. I find this very confusing. I know I’m looking for an email from Andrew about a meeting but since Jeff replies to the email I can no longer see the original email from Andrew, I can see Jeff’s reply, I have to open his reply, hoping it’s related, then scroll thru the thread to find the original email with meeting details from Andrew. 

This is very frustrating! 

Keri

title: Slow loading
text: First of all, let us admit that Outlook is very common email tool for most people in the world. Especially on computer desktop since many users are using windows. However, technology changes a lot. For personal use, people started changing something new like MacOS or Linux etc.... I am using Mac at home but I use Windows at work. I need to use email application on my phone but Outlooks Apps on my phone doesn’t work well. I tried using both Apple Mail and Outlook. And realized that Outlook loading my email very slow. It take almost 2 hours to alert my new coming email. Sometime not even show any new email. So I decided to deleted outlook from my phone and using only Apple Mail.  I will not use outlook anymore, except on computer windows at work. I give 2 stars because it has a good interface and user friendly but I need to day Good bye.

title: PLEASE let us change the color of our calendar events in app!
text:
I love this app. I got it for school/work use. I love that the email and calendar are connected in one app. I love that we can send calendar invites and see shared calendars. 

My one plea is that we would be able to change the calendar even colors from the app! We can change it from the computer, but I use my phone to check my calendar throughout the day as well as add events in immediately and as needed. I hate that I cannot change the color of events in the app. On a weekly basis, I find myself spending 10 minutes correcting and color-coding my new added events!

title: Outlook on Mobile Needs Tweaking
text: I find Outlook useful most of the time, but when it comes to my mobile use, I have encountered issues where it freezes and I have to remove the Outlook Mobile App and reinstall. I have done this at least four or five times on my iPhone and it has stalled at times I really could have benefited from having access. The last month, it has been okay. I think this is the longest stretch of not having to reinstall. Hopefully, Microsoft can look into this and come up with solutions to prevent this from occurring repeatedly. At this point, I can’t say whether it’s my phone or the mobile app. Startbucks also requires me to reset or reinstall at times.

title: Please … a redo is overdue
text: Where is the MS overhaul of the whole Outlook family that makes this app design go away forever? This aging Outlook app was cobbled together when MS bought Acompli (mail) and Sunrise (calendar). After MS bought these apps and became proud of the “focused inbox” that other developers developed, it then (July 2017) reworked the app into a clunky, busy, shelf apparatus that hides what you need to see. The engineers also replaced email account names with account icons and suddenly the multiple Gmail accounts, for example, were indistinguishable from each other. Well, duh. Check out the dog-ugly, default solution. The app also became unprofessionally juvenile: e.g., an empty drafts folder says “start writing something fabulous.” Some writing is fabulous, but not emails. We also get the notice, “Nothing left to read, well played” — a junior-high grammar mistake called a comma splice. The ONE POSITIVE: a good search engine.

title: Super email platform!
text:
I am loving the Outlook email platform. It is so much better for me than aol or Comcast. I like the set-up a lot. I am loving being able to send large emojis, that are right on my email page, to family and friends and they are all loving them too. A few of my friends switched to outlook because of my positive review and they are enjoying as well. Thanks for the opportunity..... DorisAnn... PS.... and your help desk is wonderful too!! Once I upgraded, the movable emoji’s disappeared. I would love to get them back.
But when I updated my favorite funny moving animal pictures that I would send to friends disappeared. I would love to get them back!

title: No shared inboxes or times on emails
text:
App is superior in most user-facing ways to the desktop version, with the key exception of functionality. Any Outlook user dealing with shared inboxes knows Microsoft treats this feature like an alcoholic stepparent & has for a long time; this isn’t a surprise but I’m not giving credit where it isn’t due. It isn’t in the app at all. 

Secondly: if displaying times on emails was’t useful to people, it wouldn’t be in the desktop app.

Both of these are attributable to laziness &/or lack of user understanding &/or lack of communication between the desktop team & the iOS team. We need this stuff, peeps, & you’re making our jobs more difficult to work out of iOS.

title: Fix focused inbox!
text: I have to use this app for my work email, and like that I can set default swipe functions for mail in my inbox. However, as others have said, moving emails to other folders is clunky, the search is tedious and could be much smarter with more recent and relevant results first, and the “focused” inbox doesn’t work. I have the focused/other inbox set up on my desktop/online account, but for some reason, the app shows ALL of my emails together in the focused inbox (and an empty Other). It makes my inbox almost unusable due to the amount of clutter and unimportant emails that aren’t sorted correctly. I have no idea why the app does this, but it’s extremely frustrating and defeats the purpose of organizing my inbox this way. PLEASE FIX THIS.

title: Great App... Only One Item On My Wish List
text:
The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars was because, unlike the stock iPhone app, you can't minimize a new mail and look at other emails or create a second email and minimize again, if needed. I used that feature frequently. With Outlook, you must create a draft, go find your reference email and go back to the draft. It's just a little more cumbersome. I use this app for work email 100% and it syncs with my work email at the office flawlessly. I think it's fantastic for people that use Microsoft Exchange.

I would also like to see the ability to add contact groups but that’s not an huge issue. Just an enhancement that would be nice.

title: Charm and Utility
text:
People usually scoff at Outlook, and I’ll admit I did too when I found out my current employer uses Office365.  Coming from a sweet life of Google Apps and iCal, Outlook felt like a dive into the past. 

Color me 365 shades of wrong.  This app is cute and mighty!  The calendar design is fluid and easy to use, and the mail threads are effortless to move through.  Everything I need lives on one app... I don’t have to bounce between Gmail and the iPhone Calendar and Mail and a bunch of other noise.  

Microsoft have created a lovely little product that makes handling work emergencies while on the go that much simpler.  If you use Outlook for work and haven’t downloaded this app, get it, try it out, and be dazzled.

title: Version 2.64.0 Slow loading and slow respond my
text: Just a heads up that I’m experiencing issues with the 2.64.0 version on my iPhone X and my iPad Air 2. On both, when opening the app, I’m met with a blank white screen for a long long long long long long time. I haven’t timed it but it seems like forever because the app usually loads very quickly. In addition, I find the new version becomes unresponsive very often ( must tap tap tap tap tap tap tap tap tap tap tap and wait wait wait wait wait wait wait ) to get things like the filter icon to respond. I want to be very clear that Outlook is my favorite mail app for iOS and has been for a long time but this particular version is often quite aggravating. I look forward to a fix and getting my typically excellent Outlook experience back.

title: Great email app for iPad/iPhone

title: Watch sync slow, and other shortcomings
text:
Was forced to use this app by my employer. 

Apple Watch calendar and related complication rarely updates in the background. I’ve grown to use my watch extensively for my calendar, and have almost missed meetings because they didn’t update in time (even hours before). Calendar only seems to update when the watch app is manually opened and refreshed. Bottom line - I cant rely on the watch app and complication to keep track of my schedule. And neither should you. 

I also am annoyed that I can’t have badge notifications per account. I’d like to use outlook at my only email app, replacing gmail, but I need to be able to turn off notifications for my work email on nights and weekends. Notifications per account, like the stock email app, should be easy to implement and a no brainer. Not sure why it’s missing.

title: Unreliable, glitchy, and overly complicated
text:
I get the spinning wheel of death when I try to mark a message as unread. Seriously, when I was able to use Apple's IOS mail with MS Exchange server I never had a problem marking an email as unread. With Office 365 and bring forced to use the MS Outlook app I have experienced so many problems I sometimes stop using my phone to check email. That is counter productive and defeats the whole purpose of being mobile.

Swipe left, swipe right, and long press/hold are three different actions that work different in Outlook than any other app on my phone. That means you have to learn multiple techniques to simply move or delete an email. The calendar app is even less intuitive and difficult to navigate. Again it works different and has different actions meaning you have to learn another set of commands different than email, different from the other apps on your iPhone.

title: Support makes up excuses to cover bugs
text:
I regularly jump back and forth between mail apps trying to find the best one that has the features I need.  I run my business with my iPhone/iPad and need certain features to be working.

Recently, I reported to Support that in the notes section of an event I often put a client’s phone number for future reference. If I need to contact that client, I can hard press the phone number and get a popup menu of options of what to do with the phone number like call, sent a txt message, etc.

I reported to support that after pressing one of the options, nothing happens.  Support’s reply was that the iPad wasn’t meant to make phone calls and that is why nothing happens.

Holy Cow, I couldn’t believe what I was reading.

I promptly opened several other email and calendar apps, found a phone number, and was able to do whatever I wanted from the popup menu, including send a txt or make a phone call.

Overall, I do like the app but Support personnel’s response to me was an insult if they thought I would accept that answer and go away.

title: Good but slow
text: It does a good job reading mail and removing redundant parts of conversations but I have two main complaints. First, it starts up quite a bit slower (2-3x) than the built in Mail app. This one is almost a deal breaker. Second, it doesn’t advance to the next message when I delete, move, or archive the current message. For extra credit, it would be very nice if I pressed the Back to Outlook button after following a Safari link, if it would always go back to the exact mail that had the link instead of sometimes just going to the main mailbox. I use both the iPhone and iPad versions, connecting to a work account on Office365.

title: What happened to you, Outlook?!
text:
This was a rock star email client. I have to abandon it now, because it has started losing data. I have pushed send on emails only to have them disappear. They are not received, nor in my Sent folder, nor in Drafts or some kind of outbox. I tried searching for one, and it appeared in the search results but when tapped, it is described as deleted. I just went to look for an email I sent a few days ago, when it became clear it had not been received. Vanished without a trace. This is unacceptable. This is data loss for the CORE JOB of the client, to send and receive emails. I deleted and re-created the mail account in the client, and I am still having the same issues. Losing my data is not acceptable.

Secondarily, Outlook randomly and silently fails to archive, delete, or move emails. It removes them from the inbox, but if I go to Gmail on the web, they are still there days later.

title: Good for free
text:
There are a few frustrations with the free version that I’ve had for years. One is the fact that I can’t block all the recurring junk mails that come in. There must be a limit to the number of junk mails that I can block in the free version. I report them as junk but they keep appearing multiple times a day. That is very irritating.
Also, I am trying to export my contact list as a file as it is not syncing up with my iCloud contacts. I don’t know why they are not linking and I’ve spent several hours with Apple on the phone to unsuccessfully correct the problem. I don’t know why I can’t download my outlook contact list as a file on my desktop and then try to upload the list into iCloud and reconcile discrepancies.

title: Shows promise, but needs to be better
text:
I’m primarily using this app to consolidate emails from all my microsoft accounts. However, I still cannot reliably use this and remove dependencies on the mail app or the gmail app.

My top issue with this app is that after every update, it likes to clear the cache and re-download emails from the server. This is incredibly annoying for me. The combination of auto updates + frequent metro/plane travel means there are times when I will try to start the app in offline mode to find an email to read only to find it completely blank.

Second issue - clutter. This got enabled on one of my accounts and I cannot find a way to turn it off from settings within the app. With clutter enabled on some accounts vs not on others, it’s a confusing app experience, particularly when you’re in the All accounts mode.

Issue 3 - I have multiple accounts that start with the same alphabet. When trying to toggle between accounts, it shows me the same alphabet logo with different colors (which also change after major app updates). This makes it hard to toggle between accounts as you’re constantly searching for the right account.

title: So Close to Greatness
text:
This app is near perfect, however, it desperately needs a couple of improvements.

It would be great to have the ability to select multiple messages to report them as junk or phishing, as is the case with the desktop client and from an Internet browser on a non-mobile device. Currently, when using the mobile app, one must open each individual email to report them as junk or phishing, whereas we can select multiple messages when using an Internet browser on a non-mobile device or from the desktop client.

Additional observation, when one composes an email from the mobile app, and saves it as a draft, or sends it from the mobile app, the formatting, specifically the spacing, is off. It either doesn’t add spaces between paragraphs, or adds additional spaces between paragraphs. The formatting is correct when viewing it from the mobile app, however, the formatting doesn’t convert well from mobile to desktop.

Other than that, Outlook for iOS is great.

title: Very Buggy - New Releases Cannot Be Trusted
text:
I've used this app for quite a while for my business E-Mail accounts, since I like to have them separate from my personal accounts. Nearly every time a new update is released, I have a problem. On four separate occasions ALL the E-Mail accounts were erased, forcing me to set up all my accounts again. I have quite a few. I've complained over and over about this problem in the APP, but it has not been fixed. 3 days ago they released a new version and yet again, ALL my accounts were erased.

At this point I am cutting my losses, I am done with this application, it's just too buggy. A real shame for an APP with the Microsoft name attached to it. Their quality control on this APP is seriously not up to par with the reputation of the company as a whole. They have consistently missed the mark big time with this APP.

title: Want to but can’t ...
text: ... commit to switching to the iOS Outlook app for good. As far as it goes, it’s a great concept and I love the layout, the speed and ease of integration of other services, calendars and third-party service providers. Three major issues ruin the experience, however: (1) Why don’t emails load completely? I hate having to press the “read more” button, only to find myself back up at the beginning of the message. (2) For many emails, the font is simply too little. Seriously. The native iOS mail app _always_ provides an experience with great legibility, why doesn’t Outlook? Plus, when switching to landscape mode it doesn’t make use of the full screen (huge bezels) so that doesn’t fix the problem either. (3) I wish it’d integrate iOS contacts into its system.

Recently was switched to Office 365 email for work and is driving me mad. Have an extensive archive folder system to organize all emails once they are actioned. When trying to navigate to a folder, this app does not mimic the actual order in Outlook but does some alphabetical ordering that buries the folders far down the list. Have seen via online searches that this is a feature that has been requested for years. 

I have also removed my personal Outlook account from my phone bc my personal email was displaying in the same inbox as work. (I’ve not yet done enough searching to determine if this is my issue or another dysfunction.)

title: Oh no !!! The new version screwed up "People"
text:
This is a wonderful app. Over the past few years, it just keeps getting better. Delete the “Apple Mail” app. Outlook is soooo much better and integrates smoothly with Office 365, GMail, Yahoo Mail, and any other account that I have. 

I especially like how it not only works smoothly with multiple email accounts, but fantastic integration with calendars, and to do lists. The “contacts” on iPhone within outlook is still a little clunky, but it’s much, much better than Apple contacts. 

Thanks Outlook team ! You have achieved the goals you set when you purchased this App years ago !

title: Gets the job done well
text: It’s a reliable mobile app I use daily for emails related to school. It’s easy to use and allows for labeling emails (flagged, read/unread etc.) and setting reminders and such. Sometimes it doesn’t notify me of new emails, but I check daily and it’s only happened once or twice the few years I’ve had it…it’s rather quick and painless for me to use.  I don’t know how any of my peers function without using apps like these. Using the version of this app on our school-issued computers is not great; I mostly rely on this app for quick communication with my teachers. Thanks to the people behind this 🙏

title: Widget Calendar
text:
This app is the best and I highly recommend to anyone. I’ve been enjoying all the updates that go into it and has allowed me to progress more with my daily activities.

I’m certain that this has been requested by many, but can you add a true widget calendar functionality where I can see the entire month and navigate to previous or future months without opening up the app? Of course if I wanted to add to a day or time I can click on a day and it would take me to it. Right now I’m using Widget Cal, which has what I’m looking for but I’d prefer having Outlook to be the main app that can facilitate this.

title: Good aesthetics and features but terribly slow
text: I’ve used the IOS outlook app for a few years for school and now with work. It used to work pretty great, some minor bugs and freezes but overall, good. Over the last 6-12 months it seems the app has taken a turn for the worst. I can barely type out a sentence of an email before this thing freezes or crashes, let alone send out a calendar invite. Even the swipe to archive is so slow. Understandably, I am on an iPhone XS, so I’d expect at this point some minor signs of my phones age taking root. But, every other app on my phone works just fine: no crashing nor extreme slow. The only thing I’ve found that works is deleting or archiving all but around 5 emails from my inbox, anything more, and this app is pretty much garbage. The astounding thing is that every review on here is positive...

title: Please make one improvement
text: While the app is stable and runs quickly it has one glaring deficiency, it does not support sub folders as Outlook does. This makes it unusable for me, or anyone who uses sub folders to organize their email. I have rules that sort incoming email into folders so I know which clients need my attention. This app does not notify me when new email arrives in these folders. I have to navigate to the folder and open it, then wait for new email to be downloaded. The conversation on this started before 2015, I would think the development team would have spent time resolving this I. The past 3 years. Outside of that it does work with my various accounts. Interesting that I had to override security settings in AOL to allow this app to access that account. AOL deems this app as less secure. Please update the basics of this app.

They’ve walked me through possible fixes, all with no avail. In the end I was told that they were aware of the issue, and it was a bug they were working on. I’m left having to open the app frequently to see if I have new mail. Super frustrating.

title: Way better than iOS standard email
text: I’d almost give it five stars. It’s way better than the standard app, however there are some functionality improvements it could use, especially if you use this app like I do for work and have to do filing. For example, some sub-files have same/similar names within files, and you can’t really see the structure when searching for a file folder (it’s difficult to know which folder the searched sub-folder is in), so I end up have to manually scroll, and I have a tooooooon of files, so this is cumbersome/time consuming. There’s other tweaks that could be made, and I’m sure this will just continue to improve.

title: Extremely powerful and user-friendly
text:
I used Outlook for years and my email address domain (the part after the “@“) was tied to my internet service provider.  I ended up moving and had to get a different domain, so I decided to try gmail (I didn’t know about the “outlook” domain at the time).

Gmail is very useful and I’m so glad that it was available during my moving transition, which took months.  But I’ve been spoiled by Outlook’s interface.  It’s so powerful.  And I absolutely LOVE Outlook’s Rules, with which you can redirect emails automatically so that your inbox can remain small and you have your categorized emails in their own folders.

The basics of Outlook are easy to learn.  After that, delve into how to set up different folders and use Rules.

Outlook has been around for many, many years.  It’s a mature product, which means that it’s not “buggy”.  And it comes with the entire suite of Microsoft’s most useful products -all in Microsoft 365 - for only $99/year.  For me, it’s the best email product out there.

title: Good app, but one feature drives me crazy!
text:
I find the app very straightforward and can’t beat the compatibility with the other office apps I use for work. Sometimes clicking on a PowerPoint or word doc opens the app, but doesn’t actually open the doc. After a few more tries I usually get it to work, but don’t quite know the problem there. 

The feature that drives me crazy is that, when reading a really long email inside the app, you eventually get to a button that says “Read More...” Once you click that button, the app opens your email in a separate window, BUT BUT BUT returns you to the very top of that very long email. An small annoyance but when it occurs multiple times throughout the day, it can really grate...

title: Great app for the most part.
text:
It has a great design and pretty good customizable settings. 
I cannot stand the “focused” and “other” inboxes and I was relieved to see I could turn it off. That feature does not work even a little bit. I hate having to switch in between inboxes regardless to check and see if I’m missing something important. 
The app seems much better than the default app, just a bit slower to load. Even though it’s a bit slower it seems to be much more reliable. 
All in all, I doubt there is anything better on the App Store, and I hope they continue to improve this app and add more customization options!
Thanks for a great app!

text:
Outlook used to be my favorite Gmail app on iOS but it just got worse. Microsoft just added ads at the top of inboxes. These ads look like spam/phishing emails. They’re horrible. The only way to get rid of ads is to pay for a 365 subscription. Disgusting. 

Also, where the heck did the ability to add aliases to Gmail accounts from within the app go? Yes, my aliases for my Gmail are set up on the web side. I used to be able to select an alias to send emails from my work email. Now I have to use the original email address which is a) awfully long and b) not where I want my recipients to see my email coming from. 

 Hey Microsoft, fix these things please or I’m going to have to leave Outlook and go back to the Gmail app. The app seems to lose features and get slower and worse with every update. Can’t believe this.

title: Needs Attention
text: By default the email signature is [get outlook for iOS] which it tags onto an email AFTER you press the send button. I should not have to use Google to figure out how I can write a professional email on your mobile app. Additionally why is the signature not filled in while I’m writing the email so that I could change it before sending? I cannot fathom the reasoning behind this decision. My last complaint about this “feature” is the inclusion of the shady link to download which makes no sense. For starters this is a Microsoft product. Not only is there plenty of room in the budget for actual advertising, everyone that uses a computer that isn’t a Mac has this installed from day one so people already know it exists. It makes no sense that this app would attempt to market itself through my work or my personal email.

title: Useless after the last couple of updates
text:
Outlook used to be my go-to email app superior to the Ricky dink email app that comes with an iPad.  Operating word here being “used to”.   Last couple of updates improved Outlook to the point it is totally useless.   Odd behavior that was not there before and as of today in the AM outlook on on all my mobile devices fails to work.   It hangs up for some unknown reason and once it locks up you cannot do anything with it.  Can’t read emails, it does not update email, I cannot get into settings.   It was working fine last night, it isn’t today in the am.   Argh!   My online account tied to Outlook is fine.  I logged into it and I’m getting my emails via Safari.  Argh again!
I don’t care how wonderful your features are if I don’t give me the basic ability of reading and sending emails.

title: Disappointed
text: I was excited to be able to use Outlook on my PC and on my iPhone. However, now I'm ready to uninstall outlook from both my devices completely. If I could rate it is zero I would rate outlook a zero right now. ThereIs a problem where an email titled from a business that I do want to receive email from, but all that's follows is Nonsense numbers letters etc. I get hundreds of those a day. I have taken the time on several days to report them as spam and phishing. There doesn't seem to be any way to stop it unless I block whatever the title is in each email. But I do want to receive emails from the business of that email. So that leaves me in a dilemma. I either block those emails and lose the legitimate emails from those businesses also or do not block it and have to open hundreds of nonsense emails every day. What can you do to stop this and help me before I delete outlook?

title: Do not download the newest update - it will impact your notifications
text: I wish I did not download the newest update.  My e-mail notifications changed from short notification (sender, subject line, maybe also first line of content) to a generic notification  - something like you got a new message.  There is even no way to report it to MS or get any help.  MS gives directions to report issues to go to Settings and then Help & Feedback - well, there is no option to contact MS for help or to send feedback.  So, if you want to continue getting your decent notifications - DO NOT DOWNLOAD the newest update until they fix it.

title: Outlook for IOS
text: Outlook in and of itself is great but I don’t like the way it links all of your emails together on mobile.  On mobile it links together related emails but also cuts out some of the replies throughout.  I know you can click on the 3 dots to get the full convo but it’s a little confusing to look at sometimes.  I’d prefer to click on an email and see it as a stand-alone with only the replies that pertain to that email only...not linked with other emails that weren’t necessarily a part of that exact email chain.  In other words, I’d like for it to be exactly how it is on desktop. Hope I’m describing it accurately.

title: Password.
text: 2 Days ago I could get into my computer just fine but I tried it yesterday and Microsoft had changed my computer login for some reason to its password, which I haven’t used in weeks and haven’t planned on using it again. So I try to reset it and how much information does this reset website need!? I have tried to reset it 15 times and “ there isn’t enough information given for us to prove it is you” like I didn’t tell you where I live in the first place why you gotta know now?!! So I’m currently locked out of my computer with no way to sign in.. if I could give 0 starts I know me and about more then half these reviews would.

title: Reply all is the default on group emails
text: For 3 years people have been asking to change the default reply method on group emails. Still nothing. If you receive a group email, at the bottom where the reply box is, the default method is to reply all. If you the only recipient it’s just reply. Makes sense except for the fact that we get used to just replying from the bottom box so ALWAYS end up sending reply all when it’s a group email. That’s a huge security risk because a lot of times people don’t even notice they replied to everyone. Yes you can manually select it to reply to individual instead of reply all but we get wired to just reply from that quick box because most emails are single recipient. After so much apologizing to the group, I’m at the point of switching back to standard iOS to prevent it from embarrassment.
